author: Andrew Bailey
title: Reflecting on recent times
Key quote: Policy setting will need to remain restrictive for sufficiently long until the risks to inflation remaining sustainably around the 2% target in the medium term have dissipated further.
Rationale: Andrew Bailey's speech reflects a cautious optimism about inflation pressures diminishing, but stresses the need for ongoing restrictive policy to ensure inflation expectations remain anchored and inflation is brought back to target. This suggests a somewhat hawkish stance but allowing for a moderation in policy tightening, hence a likely vote to hold rates at the next meeting.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew Bailey, Governor of the Bank of England, "Reassessing the Effectiveness and Transmission of Monetary Policy", an economic symposium sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, Jackson Hole, Wyoming, 23 August 2024.

author: Andrew Bailey
title: Banking today
Key quote: UK banks have come through the turbulence of the last four years in sound health, and that has enabled them to contribute to maintaining financial stability and to support the economy and their customers during these difficult times.
Rationale: The speech primarily focuses on banking stability and reforms rather than on direct monetary policy adjustments. While mentioning past rate hikes, there is no indication of an urgent need to change the policy stance, hence a neutral position with a tendency to hold rates.
description: Text of the Loughborough Lecture by Mr Andrew Bailey, Governor of the Bank of England, at the Loughborough Business School, Loughborough University, London, 12 February 2024.

author: Andrew Bailey
title: A measure of wheat for a penny - food price inflation in historical perspective
Key quote: Interest rates will have to stay high enough for long enough to make sure we get all the way back to the 2% target.
Rationale: The speech indicates a firm commitment to maintaining high interest rates until inflation is firmly under control, but without explicit mentioning of immediate rate hikes, suggesting a 'Hold' stance at the next meeting.
description: Text of the Henry Plumb Memorial Lecture by Mr Andrew Bailey, Governor of the Bank of England, London, 20 November 2023.

author: Andrew Bailey
title: New prospects for money
Key quote: Currently at 8.7% in the latest data, consumer price inflation is unacceptably high, and we must bring it down to the 2% target.
Rationale: Andrew Bailey's strong focus on the necessity to reduce inflation from the current high level of 8.7% to the 2% target and his mention of past and potential future policy tightening suggest a hawkish stance.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew Bailey, Governor of the Bank of England, at the Financial and Professional Services Dinner, London, 10 July 2023.

author: Andrew Bailey
title: Getting inflation back to the 2% target
Key quote: If there were to be evidence of more persistent pressures, then further tightening in monetary policy would be required.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need to control inflation and mentions that further tightening in monetary policy may be required if there is evidence of more persistent inflation pressures. This suggests a hawkish stance, likely indicating a future rate hike.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew Bailey, Governor of the Bank of England, at the British Chamber of Commerce's Global Annual Conference "Building British Business", London, 17 May 2023.

author: Andrew Bailey
title: Monetary and financial stability - lessons from recent times
Key quote: We must ensure that financial stability continues to mean that monetary policy takes into account financial conditions but does not have to aim off for instability.
Rationale: Bailey emphasizes the need for monetary policy to focus on inflation without deviating due to financial instability, alongside the implementation of Quantitative Tightening. This suggests a concern with inflation control, leaning towards hawkish sentiment. However, the absence of a systemic banking crisis and ongoing emphasis on financial stability suggests an inclination to maintain current rates.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew Bailey, Governor of the Bank of England, at the Institute of International Finance, Washington DC, 12 April 2023.

author: Andrew Bailey
title: Supply matters
Key quote: We have to be very alert to any signs of persistent inflationary pressures. If they become evident, further monetary tightening would be required.
Rationale: Andrew Bailey emphasizes the importance of avoiding persistent inflation and acknowledges the possibility of further monetary tightening. This suggests a hawkish stance focused on controlling inflation, making 'Raise' rates the most likely prediction.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew Bailey, Governor of the Bank of England, at the London School of Economics, London, 27 March 2023.

author: Andrew Bailey
title: The cost of living
Key quote: At this stage, I would caution against suggesting either that we are done with increasing Bank Rate, or that we will inevitably need to do more.
Rationale: Andrew Bailey's speech indicates concern about persistent inflationary pressures and a tight labor market, suggesting the potential need for future rate increases. However, he remains cautious about committing to further rate hikes, which balances the hawkish tone, implying a 'hold' decision is more likely at the next meeting.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew Bailey, Governor of the Bank of England, at Brunswick Group's Cost of Living Conference, London, 1 March 2023.

author: Andrew Bailey
title: Monetary policy and financial stability interventions in difficult times
Key quote: We will not hesitate to raise interest rates to meet the inflation target. And, as things stand today, my best guess is that inflationary pressures will require a stronger response than we perhaps thought in August.
Rationale: The speech indicates a strong commitment to controlling inflation with potential interest rate hikes, suggesting a hawkish stance. Andrew Bailey emphasizes readiness to raise rates if inflationary pressures persist, reflecting a priority on addressing above-target inflation.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew Bailey, Governor of the Bank of England, at the G30 37th Annual International Banking Seminar, Washington DC, 15 October 2022.

author: Andrew Bailey
title: Bringing inflation back to the 2% target, no ifs no buts
Key quote: Let me be quite clear, there are no ifs or buts in our commitment to the 2% inflation target. That's our job, and that's what we will do.
Rationale: Governor Bailey emphasizes the commitment to bringing inflation back to the 2% target and highlights considering a 50 basis point rate increase if inflation pressures persist. This indicates a somewhat hawkish stance in monetary policy.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew Bailey, Governor of the Bank of England, at the Mansion House Financial and Professional Services Dinner, London, 19 July 2022.

author: Andrew Bailey
title: The economic landscape - structural change, global R * and the missing-investment puzzle
Key quote: Bringing inflation back down to the 2% target sustainably is our job, no ifs or buts.
Rationale: Although the speech covers numerous structural and long-term themes, the emphasis on vigilance against inflationary pressures and the readiness to act forcefully suggests a tilt towards further rate increases. This aligns with a somewhat hawkish stance.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew Bailey, Governor of the Bank of England, at the Official Monetary and Financial Institutions Forum, London, 12 July 2022.

author: Andrew Bailey
title: Oesterreichische Nationalbank monetary policy panel
Key quote: We have raised the official rate four times so far and have made clear that in order to bring inflation down to target we are prepared to do so again based on the assessment at each of our meetings.
Rationale: Andrew Bailey's speech emphasizes the importance of addressing inflation and clearly states that the Bank of England is prepared to raise rates further if necessary. The repeated emphasis on taking action to meet the inflation target and prior rate increases support a hawkish stance.
description: Opening remarks by Mr Andrew Bailey, Governor of the Bank of England, at the Oesterreichische Nationalbank monetary policy panel at the Annual Economic Conference, Vienna, 23 May 2022.

author: Andrew Bailey
title: The hard yards
Key quote: All of us believe that there will need to be some modest tightening of policy to be consistent with meeting the inflation target sustainably over the medium-term.
Rationale: The speech expresses awareness of inflation risks, but stresses the uncertainty of the economic recovery and views the inflationary pressures as temporary. Bailey suggests that tightening will be necessary but proposes a wait-and-see approach, which is indicative of a neutral stance.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew Bailey, Governor of the Bank of England, at the Society of Professional Economists Annual Dinner, 27 September 2021.

author: Andrew Bailey
title: It's a recovery, but not as we know it
Key quote: It is important not to over-react to temporarily strong growth and inflation, to ensure that the recovery is not undermined by a premature tightening in monetary conditions.
Rationale: Andrew Bailey acknowledges rising inflation and the need to be cautious about inflation expectations. While he suggests inflation is temporary and emphasizes the importance of not tightening monetary policy prematurely, the careful monitoring and preparedness to use monetary tools reflect a somewhat hawkish stance. The overall tone advocates maintaining the current policy rate while being vigilant of inflationary pressures.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew Bailey, Governor of the Bank of England, Mansion House, London, 1 July 2021.

author: Andrew Bailey
title: Getting over covid
Key quote: The Committee does not intend to tighten monetary policy at least until there is clear evidence that significant progress is being made in eliminating spare capacity and achieving the 2% inflation target sustainably.
Rationale: Andrew Bailey's speech acknowledges both positive and cautionary aspects of the economic recovery, focusing on a balanced view of demand and supply shocks due to Covid. He emphasizes the role of forward guidance and the need for a recovery in supply and demand, suggesting a neutral stance toward immediate policy changes.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew Bailey, Governor of the Bank of England, at the Resolution Foundation, Mansion House, London, 8 March 2021.

author: Andrew Bailey
title: Modern challenges for the modern central bank - perspectives from the Bank of England
Key quote: The challenge currently is to raise the rate of inflation to target in the midst of a huge shock.
Rationale: Andrew Bailey's speech emphasizes the adaptation to larger shocks and the symmetrically important task of raising inflation to target, highlighting the use of accommodative monetary policy and supportive fiscal measures. This suggests a dovish stance aimed at supporting the economy through the pandemic-related challenges. However, the emphasis on independence and preparedness for future tightening prevents it from being classified as fully dovish.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew Bailey, Governor of the Bank of England, at the LSE German Symposium, virtual event, 5 February 2021.

author: Andrew Bailey
title: The future for business investment in the age of Covid and the role of financial services
Key quote: There is also a role for monetary policy here. As well as maintaining interest rates which are consistent with achieving the inflation target, in my view Quantitative Easing at a time like this can prevent an unwarranted tightening in financial conditions.
Rationale: The speech highlights the challenges of uncertainty and a lack of investment, but it also points out the resilience of the financial system and the role of QE in preventing tightening of financial conditions. The tone suggests caution, aiming to support the economy without aggressive policy changes, suggesting a likelihood to hold rates.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew Bailey, Governor of the Bank of England, at TheCityUK National Conference, virtual event, 17 November 2020.

author: Andrew Bailey
title: The central bank balance sheet as a policy tool - past, present and future
Key quote: The decision to 'go big' and to 'go fast' with QE in March 2020 - a period of market turmoil - may well have also avoided an undesirable tightening in those financial conditions.
Rationale: The speech provides a balanced discussion on the role of QE and its transmission channels without indicating a clear direction for immediate policy changes. There is consideration of the effectiveness of QE, but no strong signal toward easing or tightening monetary policy.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew Bailey, Governor of the Bank of England, at "Navigating the Decade Ahead: Implications for Monetary Policy", an economic policy symposium sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, Jackson Hole, Wyoming, 28 August 2020.

author: Huw Pill
title: Transformation and conjuncture − remarks by Huw Pill
Key quote: The single punchline is that both we, the Bank, and you, the market, need to prepare ourselves for increased usage of both our short-term and long-term repo operations.
Rationale: The speech discusses a strategic move toward a repo-driven framework for managing reserves, without signaling an immediate change in interest rate policy. The focus is on operational adjustments rather than changes in monetary policy stance, indicating a neutral position.

author: Huw Pill
title: Inflation persistence and monetary policy
Key quote: The onus remains on ensuring enough monetary tightening is delivered to 'see the job through' and sustainably return inflation to target.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the importance of addressing persistent inflation and suggests that recent positive economic signs don't necessarily reduce the need for further tightening. With a nod towards data dependency, Pill indicates a readiness to increase rates if persistent inflation pressures don't ease.
description: Text for the International Centre for Monetary and Banking Studies (ICMB) by Mr Huw Pill, Chief Economist and Executive Director for Monetary Analysis of the Bank of England, at the Graduate Institute, Geneva, 4 April 2023.

author: Huw Pill
title: Inflation is a 'wicked problem'
Key quote: Given where we stand, I still choose to emphasise the MPC's need to be watchful for signs of greater-than-expected persistence in inflationary pressure.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the importance of bringing inflation back to target but also acknowledges the significant tightening already undertaken. The emphasis on readiness to act on persistent inflationary pressure suggests a somewhat hawkish tilt, but the cautious tone of avoiding excessive tightening points towards holding rates for now.
description: Introductory remarks by Mr Huw Pill, Chief Economist and Executive Director for Monetary Analysis of the Bank of England, at the Warwick Think Tank, University of Warwick, Coventry, 16 February 2023.

author: Huw Pill
title: UK Monetary policy outlook
Key quote: Inflation in the United Kingdom is currently too high. Returning UK inflation to its 2% target on a lasting and sustainable basis is essential.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need to return inflation to target and indicates that the Bank of England is prepared to tighten monetary policy further if necessary. The emphasis on inflation persistence and the conditions in the labor market and energy prices suggest a somewhat hawkish stance, indicating a likely preference to raise rates to curb inflation.
description: Speech by Mr Huw Pill, Chief Economist and Executive Director for Monetary Analysis of the Bank of England, at the Money Market Association of New York University (Money Marketeers) Event, New York City, 9 January 2023.

author: Huw Pill
title: Monetary policy and central bank asset purchases - substitutes and complements
Key quote: As I have said on previous occasions, in my judgment there is still some more to do with Bank Rate in order to address prevailing inflationary pressures and complete the necessary normalisation of monetary policy following a decade or more of exceptional accommodation.
Rationale: The speech indicates a commitment to continue raising interest rates to combat inflationary pressures and complete monetary policy normalization. The mention of 'still some more to do with Bank Rate' suggests readiness for more rate hikes.
description: Text of the Beesley Lecture by Mr Huw Pill, Chief Economist and Executive Director for Monetary Analysis of the Bank of England, at the Institute of Directors, London, 23 November 2022.

author: Huw Pill
title: Monetary policy - an anchor in challenging times
Key quote: Given where we are, I continue to expect a significant monetary policy action at the MPC's next scheduled meeting.
Rationale: Huw Pill signals a readiness for a 'significant monetary policy response,' indicating a bias towards raising rates to combat persistent inflation and market volatility. The emphasis on tackling inflation and maintaining the credibility of the institutional framework indicates a somewhat hawkish stance.
description: Speech by Mr Huw Pill, Chief Economist and Executive Director for Monetary Analysis of the Bank of England, at the Scottish Council for Development and Industry, Glasgow, 12 October 2022.

author: Huw Pill
title: Recent developments in the economy and markets
Key quote: It is hard to avoid the conclusion that the fiscal easing announced last week will prompt a significant and necessary monetary policy response in November.
Rationale: Huw Pill highlights the impacts of recent fiscal easing and market developments which seem to indicate a need for a monetary policy response, likely an interest rate rise, to address inflationary pressures.
description: Speech by Mr Huw Pill, Chief Economist and Executive Director for Monetary Analysis of the Bank of England, at the Institute of Directors NI Annual Dinner, Holywood, County Down, 29 September 2022.

author: Huw Pill
title: Returning inflation to target
Key quote: Acting to achieve the 2% inflation target is now more important than ever.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes a strong commitment to addressing inflation and suggests a readiness to tighten monetary policy further if necessary. There is a focus on persistent inflationary pressures and willingness to act forcefully, indicating a hawkish stance.
description: Speech by Mr Huw Pill, Chief Economist and Executive Director for Monetary Analysis of the Bank of England, at the Kings College, London and Qatar Centre for Global Banking and Finance conference, London, 6 July 2022.

author: Huw Pill
title: What did the monetarists ever do for us?
Key quote: The current challenge for UK monetary policy is to contain those second round effects and return inflation to target as global energy and goods prices stabilise or revert in the coming years.
Rationale: Pill acknowledges the current elevated inflation largely stemming from external shocks and the necessity of addressing second-round effects. This suggests a somewhat hawkish stance, advocating preparedness to act 'forcefully' if required, pointing towards a likelihood to raise interest rates.
description: Speech by Mr Huw Pill, Chief Economist and Executive Director for Monetary Analysis of the Bank of England, at the Walter Eucken Institut / Stiftung Geld und Währung Conference "Inflation and Debt: Challenges for Monetary Policy after Covid-19", Freiburg (Germany), 24 June 2022.

author: Huw Pill
title: The economic situation and monetary policy
Key quote: In my view, we still have some way to go in our monetary policy tightening, in order to make the return of inflation to target secure.
Rationale: Huw Pill emphasizes the need to continue tightening monetary policy due to high inflation rates well above the target, and expresses a priority to further raise rates to manage this inflation. His discussion on the persistence of inflationary pressures and incomplete transition suggests a likelihood of supporting rate hikes.
description: Speech by Mr Huw Pill, Chief Economist and Executive Director for Monetary Analysis of the Bank of England, at the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA) Cymru Wales, Cardiff, 20 May 2022.

author: Huw Pill
title: Monetary policy with a steady hand
Key quote: We have signalled that more is to come in the coming months if the path sketched out in our February forecast plays out.
Rationale: While acknowledging uncertainty, the speaker emphasizes the likelihood of further rate hikes due to continued inflationary pressures and describes a measured but ongoing tightening of monetary policy.
description: Speech by Mr Huw Pill, Chief Economist and Executive Director for Monetary Analysis of the Bank of England, given at the Society of Professional Economists online conference 2022, 9 February 2022.

author: Clare Lombardelli
title: Managing the present, shaping the future - speech by Clare Lombardelli
Key quote: The optimal strategy for a policymaker under the uncertainties likely to be evident going forward, of increased volatility that is upward-inflation-biased, is an activist one, rather than the gradualist approach to policymaking.
Rationale: The speech discusses both the historical role of 'good policy' and 'good luck' in economic stability but emphasizes the need for ongoing vigilance and adaptation to new global and domestic sources of volatility. Given these uncertainties, the approach appears neutral, focused on maintaining stability rather than making immediate rate changes, suggesting a 'Hold' stance for the next interest rate meeting.
description: In her first speech as Deputy Governor for Monetary Policy, Clare Lombardelli sets out her views on the UK economy and the risks to the outlook. She then presents the Bank's plan to implement the Bernanke Review.

author: David Ramsden
title: Outlier or laggard - divergence and convergence in the UK's recent inflation performance
Key quote: Over the last few months, I have become more confident in the evidence that risks to persistence in domestic inflation pressures are receding, helped by improved inflation dynamics.
Rationale: Ramsden acknowledges improved inflation dynamics and reduced inflation persistence risks, suggesting a more dovish stance compared to previous positions. However, he maintains that policy should remain restrictive, implying a likelihood of holding rates steady at the next meeting.
description: Speech by Sir David Ramsden, Deputy Governor for Markets and Banking of the Bank of England, at the Peterson Institute of International Economics, Washington DC, 19 April 2024.

author: David Ramsden
title: Bond trading, innovation and evolution - a Bank of England perspective
Key quote: Let me summarise my position as one of a majority of MPC members who judged that maintaining Bank Rate at 5.25% was warranted at the time of our last announcement on 1 February.
Rationale: The speech covers the Bank's ongoing quantitative tightening and innovation efforts without suggesting immediate changes to the policy rate. Ramsden supports maintaining a balanced view, reflecting a cautious yet neutral stance on monetary policy.
description: Speech by Sir David Ramsden, Deputy Governor for Markets and Banking of the Bank of England, at the Association for Financial Markets in Europe (AFME) Bond Trading, Innovation and Evolution Forum, London, 27 February 2024.

author: David Ramsden
title: Back to the future
Key quote: Given my assessment of the outlook and the risks I would not rule out having to respond to evidence of more persistent inflationary pressures by raising Bank Rate further in the future but I will continue to make my decisions meeting to meeting conditional on my assessment on developments in the economy and what they indicate about prospects for inflation.
Rationale: Ramsden emphasizes the need to maintain a restrictive policy stance for an extended period, indicating concern over inflation persistence. However, he does not explicitly advocate for an immediate rate hike, hence the likelihood of holding rates at the next meeting.
description: Speech by Sir David Ramsden, Deputy Governor for Markets and Banking of the Bank of England, at the Society of Professional Economists Annual Conference, hosted by Bloomberg Bank, London, 17 November 2023.

author: David Ramsden
title: Going with the flow - how liquidity risks have evolved in the higher rate environment
Key quote: The MPC's latest projections indicate that monetary policy is likely to need to be restrictive for an extended period of time.
Rationale: The speech outlines a lack of intent to adjust interest rates for financial stability reasons and emphasizes the need for restrictive monetary policy to manage inflation, suggesting a somewhat hawkish stance. Given the context, a hold on rates is likely, allowing the central bank to assess the effects of current policies.
description: Speech (virtual) by Sir David Ramsden, Deputy Governor for Markets and Banking of the Bank of England, at the 7th Annual Conference of the European Systemic Risk Board "Financial stability challenges ahead: emerging risks and regulation", Frankfurt am Main, 16 November 2023.

author: David Ramsden
title: Quantitative tightening - the story so far
Key quote: If there is evidence of more persistent pressures, then further tightening in monetary policy would be required.
Rationale: Sir David Ramsden emphasizes the importance of addressing persistently high inflation, reflecting a hawkish stance. He suggests potential for increased gilt reduction and acknowledges the possibility of further monetary tightening if inflationary pressures persist. These comments suggest a preference towards raising interest rates to manage inflation.
description: Speech by Sir David Ramsden, Deputy Governor for Markets, Banking and Resolution of the Bank of England, at a Bank of England's event, organised by the Money Macro and Finance Society, London, 19 July 2023.

author: David Ramsden
title: That was the year that was
Key quote: I expect that further increases in Bank rate are going to be required to ensure a sustainable return of inflation to target.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes concerns about persistent inflationary pressures, the need for further rate increases, and the readiness to respond forcefully to inflation risks, indicating a hawkish stance.
description: Speech by Sir David Ramsden, Deputy Governor for Markets, Banking and Resolution of the Bank of England, at the Bank of England Watchers' Conference, organised by the Money Macro Finance Society and King's Business School at King's College, London, 24 November 2022.

author: David Ramsden
title: Shocks, inflation, and the policy response
Key quote: In my view a faster policy tightening at the last MPC meeting would have helped to bring inflation back to the 2% target sustainably in the medium term and would reduce the risks of a more extended and costly tightening later.
Rationale: David Ramsden clearly signals a preference for tighter monetary policy, emphasizing the risk of above-target inflation expectations and his previous votes for aggressive rate hikes.
description: Speech by Sir David Ramsden, Deputy Governor for Markets, Banking and Resolution of the Bank of England, at the Securities Industry Conference, London, 7 October 2022.

author: David Ramsden
title: Message received and understood
Key quote: I will conclude with a brief recap on UK financial market developments this week and highlight the use we are making of real-time data to respond to those developments to meet our objective for financial stability.
Rationale: The speech focuses on technical and structural issues like payments data and market developments rather than explicit monetary policy signals. Though financial stability concerns led to temporary interventions, there's no direct indication of changes to interest rates, suggesting a neutral stance.
description: Speech (remotely) by Sir David Ramsden, Deputy Governor for Markets, Banking and Resolution of the Bank of England, at a conference by the Bank of Lithuania and the Bank for International Settlements (BIS) on the "Future of Central Banking", 29 September 2022.

author: David Ramsden
title: Navigating the economy through the Covid crisis
Key quote: I can envisage those conditions for considering tightening being met somewhat sooner than I had previously expected.
Rationale: David Ramsden highlighted that the economic outlook had improved and that inflation was overshooting, suggesting a diminished likelihood of spare capacity. Despite the somewhat hawkish tone, he indicated that conditions were not yet met for tightening, hinting at a 'hold' stance while watching economic developments closely.
description: Speech by Sir David Ramsden, Deputy Governor for Markets and Banking of the Bank of England, at The Strand Group, King's Business School, virtual, 14 July 2021.

author: David Ramsden
title: QE as an economic policy tool - what does it do and how should we use it?
Key quote: I continue to see the current stance of policy as appropriate, given the current degree of uncertainty around the health and economic outlook.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes understanding and assessing QE as a tool, with confidence in its effectiveness so far, suggesting no immediate aggressive policy changes. Ramsden expresses readiness for potential changes but no clear inclination towards immediate alteration of the policy rate, indicating a neutral stance in maintaining the current monetary policy approach.
description: Speech by Sir David Ramsden, Deputy Governor for Markets and Banking of the Bank of England, at the Peter Sinclair Town Hall lecture, University of Birmingham, 17 February 2021.

author: David Ramsden
title: The potential long-term economic effects of Covid
Key quote: Our view, as we spelt out in our Minutes, was that risk management considerations implied that policy should lean strongly against downside risks to the outlook.
Rationale: The speech reflects concerns about long-term economic scarring from the pandemic and highlights significant recent monetary easing measures as well as forward guidance indicating a high bar for policy tightening. While concerns about scarring and the large asset purchase program indicate dovish sentiment, the speech does not suggest an immediate further cut, hence predicting 'Hold'.
description: Speech by Sir David Ramsden, Deputy Governor for Markets and Banking of the Bank of England, at the Institute for Policy and Engagement at University of Nottingham, Nottingham, 17 November 2020.

author: David Ramsden
title: The monetary policy toolbox in the UK
Key quote: We have policy tools still available, and scope remaining to use those tools.
Rationale: The speech highlights the unprecedented nature of the COVID-19 crisis and the extensive use of the monetary policy toolbox, suggesting a cautious stance. Although the deputy governor indicates that there are still tools available, there is a significant emphasis on the uncertainties and potential headwinds facing the economy. This suggests a reluctance to cut rates further, especially given the concerns about negative rates, and an acknowledgment of having tools left, hinting at a bias towards holding the current policy rate.
description: Speech by Sir David Ramsden, Deputy Governor for Markets and Banking of the Bank of England, to the Society of Professional Economists, virtual, 21 October 2020.

author: David Ramsden
title: Resilience - three lessons from the financial crisis
Key quote: Looking ahead, if we get a smooth Brexit with a transition deal, as assumed in the MPC's latest Inflation Report forecast, I expect growth to pick up, leading to excess demand and building domestic inflationary pressure, so that further monetary tightening is appropriate to maintain monetary stability.
Rationale: Sir David Ramsden balances some optimism for growth amid Brexit uncertainties with the need for future monetary tightening, indicating a somewhat hawkish stance. However, the present uncertainties suggest that the next interest rate decision is more likely to be a hold.
description: Speech by Sir David Ramsden, Deputy Governor for Markets and Banking of the Bank of England, to the Inverness Chamber of Commerce, Inverness, 30 May 2019.

author: David Ramsden
title: Finding the right balance
Key quote: In August 2018 the MPC voted to raise Bank Rate from 0.5% to 0.75%.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need for gradual rate increases to control inflation, signaling a somewhat hawkish stance towards tightening monetary policy.
description: Speech by Sir David Ramsden, Deputy Governor for Markets and Banking of the Bank of England, at the Society of Professional Economists Annual Conference, London, 28 September 2018.

author: David Ramsden
title: What's going on?
Key quote: Despite the backdrop of uncertainty, and despite the unusual things going on in the economy, I am actually reasonably confident about our understanding of what's going on.
Rationale: The speech outlines both the concerns and potential paths for the UK economy, showing awareness of inflation pressures but also considerable uncertainties, which suggests a neutral stance. Sir David Ramsden emphasizes a watchful approach, implying holding rates until clearer data is available.
description: Speech by Sir David Ramsden, Deputy Governor for Markets and Banking of the Bank of England, at the Barclays Inflation Conference, London, 7 June 2018.

author: David Ramsden
title: The UK's productivity growth challenge
Key quote: The weakness of and uncertainty around the path of UK productivity is a key driver of these unusual developments, and is therefore a key consideration for monetary policy.
Rationale: The speech presents a balanced view on productivity, with risks indicated in both directions. The mention of a slight increase in productivity does not provide a strong case for changing rates, suggesting a likelihood to hold rates constant at the next meeting.
description: Speech by Sir David Ramsden, Deputy Governor for Markets and Banking of the Bank of England, at an East of England CBI event, Cambridge, 23 February 2018.

author: David Ramsden
title: Monetary policy from end to end - define, decide, deliver
Key quote: For that reason, in our November meeting I was willing to wait for more evidence on the evolution of wage and domestic cost growth before beginning to withdraw some monetary stimulus.
Rationale: Sir David Ramsden's speech outlines a balanced view on the economic situation, highlighting uncertainties and the need for further evidence before adjusting rates. He notes the subdued nature of domestic inflation and labor market flexibility, suggesting a cautious approach, thereby leaning towards holding the current rate.
description: Speech by Sir David Ramsden, Deputy Governor for Markets and Banking of the Bank of England, The Strand Group Lecture Series, King's College London, London, 20 November 2017.

author: Sarah Breeden
title: Engineering revisited
Key quote: As I have become more confident that persistence is likely to evolve as embodied within our forecast, I have become less concerned that rates might need to be tightened further.
Rationale: Sarah Breeden expresses reduced concern about inflation persistence, which suggests comfort with the current policy stance and implies a reduced likelihood of further rate hikes. Her emphasis on assessing real-world outcomes indicates a preference to hold the rate steady and observe developments, particularly regarding persistence and wage growth.
description: Speech by Ms Sarah Breeden, Deputy Governor for Financial Stability of the Bank of England, at the UK Women in Economics Annual Networking Event, London, 7 February 2024.

author: Sarah Breeden
title: Monetary policy as engineering?
Key quote: The economy is moving in the right direction to return inflation to the 2% target, but our job isn't done. The question I am focused on is whether there is evidence of more persistent inflationary pressures which means we may need to tighten further.
Rationale: Sarah Breeden emphasizes the need for monetary policy to remain restrictive to combat persistent inflation, showing concern about high inflation as the more costly scenario. However, she also balances this with acknowledgment of uncertainty and the importance of current evidence, leading her to support a 'Hold' stance for now.
description: Speech by Ms Sarah Breeden, Deputy Governor and member of the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) of the Bank of England, at the Institute of International Finance's Talking Policy Series, 19 December 2023.

author: Sarah Breeden
title: Two sides of the same coin - delivering monetary and financial stability timelessly
Key quote: Monetary and financial stability are complementary, representing two sides of the same coin.
Rationale: The speech addresses the complexity of the relationship between monetary and financial stability and highlights the importance of both. While it acknowledges the need for vigilance as monetary policy tightens, it does not signal an immediate need to alter interest rates, suggesting a neutral stance.
description: Speech by Ms Sarah Breeden, Executive Director for Financial Stability Strategy and Risk of the Bank of England, at the University of Leeds, Leeds, 9 March 2023.

author: Swati Dhingra
title: A cost-of-living crisis: Inflation during an unprecedented terms of trade shock - speech by Swati Dhingra
Key quote: Overtightening poses a more material risk at this point, through potential negative impacts from increased borrowing costs and reduced supply capacity going forwards.
Rationale: The speaker highlights the risks of overtightening and argues that the evidence does not point to persistent cost-push inflation becoming embedded in wages and margins. The suggestion is to hold policy steady, indicating a dovish stance.

author: Megan Greene
title: Worlds apart? UK inflation and monetary policy in an international context - speech by Megan Greene
Key quote: I think the burden of proof therefore needs to lie in inflation persistence continuing to wane.
Rationale: The speech highlights both potential upside and downside risks for inflation due to labor hoarding, indicating a balanced assessment that does not strongly push towards policy adjustment. The likelihood of holding rates is increased given the acknowledgment of inflation persistence waning.
description: Megan Greene looks at the UK in an international context, focusing on how the drivers of inflation differ between the UK and US. She highlights evidence of greater inflation persistence in the UK and discusses how this impacts her policy stance.

author: Megan Greene
title: Are we there yet? A journey into monetary policy and medium-term factors − speech by Megan Greene
Key quote: Given recent developments in demand and inflation, it’s clear that monetary policy is restrictive in the UK. But in light of the persistence of UK wage and services price pressures, which stand out in international comparisons, I think policy will need to remain restrictive for some time in order for inflation to sustainably return to target.
Rationale: Megan Greene expresses concern over inflation persistence in the UK, emphasizing the need for maintaining a restrictive policy stance due to wage and services price pressures. However, she also acknowledges recent downside news in wage growth and signs of easing persistence, suggesting holding the rate at 5.25% for now.
description: In her first speech as an MPC member, Megan sets out her approach to interest rate decisions. She weighs the risks of inflation persistence, in particular services inflation and wage growth, with weakening activity. Megan then considers how the UK’s medium-term outlook may have shifted and what this could mean for monetary policy.

author: Catherine L Mann
title: Climate policy and monetary policy: interactions and implications - speech by Catherine L. Mann
Key quote: The Bank considers that, if underlying inflation rises in line with its outlook, it will be appropriate to accordingly raise the policy interest rate and adjust the degree of monetary accommodation.
Rationale: The speech discusses favorable economic conditions, moderate price rises, and underlying inflation approaching the target. The call for potentially raising rates suggests a somewhat hawkish stance, despite reiterating the need for careful monitoring of various risks.
description: Catherine L. Mann talks about the importance of considering climate change for monetary policy. She discusses climate mitigation policies and their macroeconomic effects, by drawing on her experience as an international trade economist. She analyses the implications for monetary policymakers.

author: Catherine L Mann
title: Inflation models and research: distilling dynamics for monetary policy decision-making - speech by Catherine...
Key quote: The Bank judged it appropriate to raise the policy interest rate and adjust the degree of monetary accommodation from the perspective of sustainable and stable achievement of the 2 percent price stability target.
Rationale: The speaker acknowledges the need to raise the policy interest rate and highlights upside risks to inflation, suggesting a proactive approach to managing monetary conditions and aiming to achieve the 2 percent inflation target, which signifies a somewhat hawkish stance.

author: Catherine L Mann
title: Expectations, lags, and the transmission of monetary policy - speech by Catherine L. Mann
Key quote: This leads me to my conclusion that further tightening and sooner rather than later likely is needed to ensure the effectiveness of monetary policy to achieve the objective of 2% sustainably in the medium term.
Rationale: The speech strongly indicates the need for additional monetary tightening to control inflation expectations and ensure policy effectiveness, suggesting a hawkish stance.

author: Catherine L Mann
title: Turning Points and Monetary Policy Strategy - speech by Catherine L. Mann
Key quote: We need to stay the course, and in my view the next step in Bank Rate is still more likely to be another hike than a cut or hold.
Rationale: Catherine L. Mann emphasizes the need for maintaining a robust monetary policy and suggests that the next step in Bank Rate is more likely to be another hike. She expresses concern over inflation persistence and the risks of under-tightening, supporting a hawkish viewpoint.
description: Catherine L. Mann talks about how we use data to spot turning points in the economy. She explains how that feeds into her policy decision.

author: Catherine L Mann
title: Inflation expectations, inflation persistence, and monetary policy strategy – speech by Catherine L....
Key quote: The drift in medium-term expectations is the major cause of concern, and cutting-edge research indicates that monetary policy can directly influence expectations.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the importance of moving decisively to prevent inflation expectations from becoming unanchored. With concerns about medium-term expectations drifting upwards, the need for a more aggressive monetary stance to ensure inflation returns to the 2% target is clear.
description: Catherine L. Mann describes how inflation expectations affect the Phillips curve. She then presents data on survey and financial market expectations about inflation in the short, medium, and long run. She analyses whether these are consistent with our 2% inflation target and what that implies for monetary policy strategy.

author: Catherine L Mann
title: UK monetary policy in the context of global spillovers – speech by Catherine L. Mann
Key quote: I voted for a 50 basis point increase at the last MPC meeting. In my view, a more robust policy move, based on both domestic conjuncture and commensurate with the global factor, reduces the risk that domestic inflation already embedded is further boosted by inflation imported via a Sterling depreciation.
Rationale: Catherine L. Mann expresses a strong inclination towards raising rates amidst high inflation pressures and global spillovers, indicating a robust policy move is needed. This implies a hawkish stance likely to result in increased rates in the next meeting.
description: Catherine L. Mann says changes in interest rates in the US can affect the UK economy. And she explains how that has influenced her thinking on what should happen to interest rates in the UK.

author: Catherine L Mann
title: A monetary policymaker faces uncertainty − speech by Catherine L Mann
Key quote: A front-loaded tightening path was needed to send a strong signal of commitment to the inflation target so as to forestall the embedding of inflation expectations in wages and prices.
Rationale: Catherine L Mann emphasizes the need to address inflationary pressures and expectations with bold action, favoring a strong and front-loaded tightening stance to signal commitment to the inflation target. Despite recent uncertainties, the focus remains on preventing the embedding of inflation expectations, suggesting a somewhat hawkish outlook.
description: Catherine L Mann talks about the impact of recent economic shocks and the uncertainties around them. Then she sets out her views on what this means for her monetary policy strategy in the past months and going forward.

author: Catherine L Mann
title: On returning inflation back to target - speech by Catherine L Mann
Key quote: What monetary policy needs to do now is to temper the 2022 expectations for wage and price increases to prevent them from being embedded in the decision-making of firms and consumers.
Rationale: The speech indicates concern about inflation expectations becoming embedded, and a need for monetary policy to counteract these dynamics, suggesting a preference for raising the interest rate.

author: Ben Broadbent
title: From NICE-to not so nice
Key quote: If things continue to evolve with its forecasts - forecasts that suggest policy will have to become less restrictive at some point - then it's possible Bank Rate could be cut some time over the summer.
Rationale: Ben Broadbent discusses the challenges posed by global supply shocks and indicates a potential easing of monetary policy in the near future. The speech suggests a cautious approach towards inflation, with the possibility of reducing interest rates, reflecting a somewhat dovish stance despite the current high policy rate.
description: Speech by Mr Ben Broadbent, Deputy Governor for Monetary Policy of the Bank of England, at the Bank of England, London, 20 May 2024.

author: Ben Broadbent
title: Signal versus noise
Key quote: It takes time to understand the forces driving the economy, particularly if one's having to rely on nominal variables like services inflation and wage growth, things that would normally be seen as late-cycle indicators.
Rationale: Ben Broadbent's speech reflects uncertainty about economic data and acknowledges situations that can lead to delayed policy reactions. He highlights the need for careful monitoring of wage growth and other variables before making policy decisions. The emphasis on balancing data uncertainty suggests a neutral stance, likely leaning towards holding the policy rate until clearer trends emerge.
description: Speech by Mr Ben Broadbent, Deputy Governor for Monetary Policy of the Bank of England, at the London Business School, London, 18 December 2023.

author: Ben Broadbent
title: The economic costs of restricting trade - the experience of the UK
Key quote: It is likely that monetary policy will have to remain in restrictive territory for some time.
Rationale: Broadbent signals that despite recent declines in import costs, the Bank of England anticipates needing to keep monetary policy tight to control inflationary pressures stemming from recent supply shocks and a tight labor market.
description: Speech by Mr Ben Broadbent, Deputy Governor for Monetary Policy of the Bank of England, at "Structural Shifts in the Global Economy", an economic policy symposium sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, Jackson Hole, Wyoming, 26 August 2023.

author: Ben Broadbent
title: The inflationary consequences of real shocks
Key quote: The MPC will ensure the inflationary effects do not persist into the medium term; but the real-income hit exists either way, and will be reversed only to the extent the underlying shocks themselves go away.
Rationale: The speaker acknowledges that while import prices may stabilize, domestic inflation remains a concern, requiring a tightening of monetary policy to address persistent inflation.
description: Speech by Mr Ben Broadbent, Deputy Governor for Monetary Policy of the Bank of England, at the Imperial College, London, 20 October 2022.

author: Ben Broadbent
title: Reliable partners
Key quote: It's not that monetary authorities are unconcerned about expectations of future interest rates. Quite the opposite: these expectations are central to the transmission of policy.
Rationale: Broadbent acknowledges the external shocks and the resulting high inflation, suggesting a cautious approach with a likelihood to hold, given the current economic uncertainty and reliance on economic developments for future policy decisions.
description: Speech by Mr Ben Broadbent, Deputy Governor for Monetary Policy of the Bank of England, at the Gresham College, London, 30 March 2022.

author: Ben Broadbent
title: Lags, trade-offs and the challenges facing monetary policy
Key quote: Although it's made little contribution to higher inflation so far, the risks to future inflation from the tight labour market may well be more significant.
Rationale: The speech addresses rising inflation and the pressure on the labor market, suggesting a concern over inflation persistence and the potential need for tighter monetary policy. The focus on inflation exceeding 5% and tight labor conditions implies a tilt towards raising interest rates.
description: Speech by Mr Ben Broadbent, Deputy Governor for Monetary Policy of the Bank of England, at the Leeds University Business School, Leeds, 6 December 2021.

author: Ben Broadbent
title: Mismatch
Key quote: I'm not convinced that the current inflation in retail goods prices should in and of itself mean higher inflation 18-24 months ahead, the horizon more relevant for monetary policy.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges the current rapid economic growth and forecasts inflation to exceed 3%. While the Deputy Governor notes several temporary factors driving inflation and uncertainties around supply and demand mismatches, his emphasis on monitoring labor costs suggests caution. The balanced discussion suggests a somewhat hawkish stance, likely leaning towards holding rates to observe further developments.
description: Speech by Mr Ben Broadbent, Deputy Governor for Monetary Policy of the Bank of England, at the Bank of England, 22 July 2021.

author: Ben Broadbent
title: Covid and the composition of spending
Key quote: The Committee has also said that it would need firm evidence of a significant narrowing in spare capacity, and of a sustainable return of inflation to the 2% target, before considering whether to withdraw any of this stimulus.
Rationale: The speech is analytical and focused on understanding consumer behavior and spending patterns during the pandemic, without strong indications of an urgent need to change monetary policy. This suggests a wait-and-see approach to interest rates until further evidence about inflation trends and labor market conditions are available.
description: Speech by Mr Ben Broadbent, Deputy Governor for Monetary Policy of the Bank of England, Webinar, 12 January 2021.

author: Ben Broadbent
title: Government debt and inflation
Key quote: Aggressive monetary easing by central banks, occurring as it has alongside very large government deficits, has raised fears in some quarters about 'monetary finance'. These are misplaced.
Rationale: The speech focuses on discussing the relationship between government debt, inflation, and monetary policy, emphasizing the independence of monetary policy in targeting inflation, and downplaying the causal link between fiscal deficits and monetary policy moves suggest a neutral stance. While inflationary pressures are not seen as imminent, the recognition of ongoing monetary easing indicates a prediction to 'Hold' the rate steady.
description: Speech (via videolink) by Mr Ben Broadbent, Deputy Governor for Monetary Policy of the Bank of England, at the 2020 Annual Meeting of the Central Bank Research Association, London, 2 September 2020.

author: Ben Broadbent
title: Investment and uncertainty - the value of waiting for news
Key quote: Business investment fell in every quarter last year and surveys suggest the underlying trend is still negative.
Rationale: The speech heavily emphasizes uncertainty's negative impact on investment, particularly due to Brexit, but there's no direct indication that suggests a rate cut or increase. The concern for investment might lean dovish, but the nuanced view suggests a recommended policy hold.
description: Speech by Mr Ben Broadbent, Deputy Governor for Monetary Policy of the Bank of England, at the Imperial College Business School, London, 20 May 2019.

author: Ben Broadbent
title: Debt dynamics
Key quote: Even if low bond yields don't presage rapid growth of house prices, one thing they do suggest is that interest payments on mortgage debt will also remain relatively low.
Rationale: The speech discusses insights into debt growth and its predictive power for financial distress, suggesting a cautious approach to debt monitoring. There's no strong indication of a need for immediate policy change, justifying a neutral stance.
description: Speech by Mr Ben Broadbent, Deputy Governor for Monetary Policy of the Bank of England, at the London Business School, London, 23 January 2019.

author: Ben Broadbent
title: The history and future of QE
Key quote: Our task remains to hit the inflation target and we will always seek to ensure that the combined effects of the APF and of more conventional changes in Bank Rate are set to that end.
Rationale: The speech discusses the historical impacts and future considerations of QE without indicating an immediate change in monetary policy, suggesting a neutral stance with a likelihood to maintain current rates.
description: Speech by Mr Ben Broadbent, Deputy Governor for Monetary Policy of the Bank of England, at the Society of Professional Economists, London, 23 July 2018.

author: Ben Broadbent
title: Brexit and interest rates
Key quote: That's why I think it was the right thing to remove a degree of monetary accommodation.
Rationale: Broadbent emphasizes a concern for above-target inflation and diminishing spare capacity. He suggests that the recent rate increase was appropriate, indicating a tendency toward further tightening if conditions persist.
description: Speech by Mr Ben Broadbent, Deputy Governor for Monetary Policy of the Bank of England, at the London School of Economics, London, 15 November 2017.

author: Ben Broadbent
title: Brexit and the pound
Key quote: In its latest forecasts the MPC expects this caution to persist. That's why, in the central projection in the February Inflation Report, growth slows slightly this year, from 2.0% at the end of last year to 1.7% by 2017Q4.
Rationale: The speech focuses on the implications of Brexit on the exchange rate and economic responses without a strong indication towards tightening or loosening the monetary policy, leading to a neutral stance. The discussion on exchange rate effects and capacity constraints implies a 'Hold' position on rates until more clarity on Brexit outcomes emerges.
description: Speech by Mr Ben Broadbent, Deputy Governor for Monetary Policy of the Bank of England, at the Imperial College, London, 23 March 2017.

author: Ben Broadbent
title: Uncertain times
Key quote: The key judgement for the MPC was that this uncertainty would itself weigh on demand and investment spending in particular.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges uncertainty and highlights the cushioning effect of the exchange rate depreciation on economic activity. While noting that some aspects like investment might be affected, it doesn't suggest immediate further easing, hence a 'Hold' prediction.
description: Speech by Mr Ben Broadbent, Deputy Governor for Monetary Policy of the Bank of England, at the Wall Street Journal, London, 5 October 2016.

author: Jonathan Haskel
title: UK inflation since the pandemic: How did we get here and where are we going? − speech by Jonathan Haskel
Key quote: Regarding the future conduct of monetary policy, if the outlook for economic activity and prices that I have outlined today is realized, the Bank will accordingly continue to raise the policy interest rate and adjust the degree of monetary accommodation.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the shift from cost-push inflation to domestic wage-driven inflation and highlights the Bank of Japan's plan to continue raising policy interest rates if economic projections are met. This indicates a somewhat hawkish stance as the focus is on adjusting monetary policy in response to improving economic conditions.

author: Jonathan Haskel
title: Implications of current wage inflation − speech by Jonathan Haskel
Key quote: If this outlook is realized, I think it will be necessary for the Bank to raise the short-term policy interest rate to a level that is neutral to economic activity and prices.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the necessity to raise interest rates to address potential upside risks to inflation and to achieve the price stability target sustainably. The speaker suggests a gradual approach to raising the rate, indicating a likelihood of voting to raise rates at the next meeting.
description: Jonathan talks about recent UK wage growth, and why it might be as high as it appears to be. He considers some measurement issues, and then constructs a simple economic model of wages. Finally, he considers some economic explanations for an increase in the equilibrium rate of unemployment, which may be contributing to current high wage growth.

author: Jonathan Haskel
title: What’s driving inflation: wages, profits, or energy prices? − speech by Jonathan Haskel
Key quote: Further increases in Bank rate cannot be ruled out.
Rationale: The speaker acknowledges current inflation concerns, emphasizes the tight labor market, the risks of inflation momentum, and indicates that further rate hikes are possible to control inflation, signaling a hawkish stance.

author: Jonathan Haskel
title: Recent UK monetary policy in a changing economy − speech by Jonathan Haskel
Key quote: I voted for a 75 basis points increase, which is the largest UK increase since 1989.
Rationale: Jonathan Haskel's speech emphasizes the importance of addressing inflationary pressures, particularly due to energy prices and a tight labor market. He supports rate hikes to counter persistent inflation, indicating a hawkish stance.
description: In this speech Jonathan Haskel talks about inflation in the UK economy. He explains how energy prices affect inflation, why inflation is expected to fall quite sharply in 2023 and 2024, and how the shortage of workers in the economy plays a role in driving inflation. He discusses how these factors interact, and why he voted to raise interest rates by 0.75% at the November 2022 Monetary Policy Meeting, in order to prevent inflation from becoming persistent.

author: Jonathan Haskel
title: Current monetary policy – opening remarks by Jonathan Haskel
Key quote: The MPC has the tools and resolve to return inflation to target in the medium term.
Rationale: The speech centers around the importance of institutions and monetary policy tools, emphasizing the medium-term inflation target and showing no urgency to change the current rate policy, indicating a neutral stance.

author: Jonathan Haskel
title: Inflation now and then - speech by Jonathan Haskel
Key quote: In my view, if the labour market stays tight, Bank Rate will have to rise.
Rationale: Haskel acknowledges the current high inflation and tight labor market conditions, suggesting that the Bank Rate will need to rise. While he sees much of the inflation as transitory, he emphasizes vigilance and the likelihood of a rate increase, indicating a somewhat hawkish stance.

author: Jonathan Haskel
title: Will the pandemic “scar” the economy? - remarks by Jonathan Haskel
Key quote: For the foreseeable future, in my view, tight policy isn’t the right policy.
Rationale: The speech highlights positive signs for the supply side of the economy, reducing the need for immediate policy tightening despite acknowledging inflationary pressures. The focus on scarring and caution against pre-emptive tightening suggests a dovish stance, but an acknowledgment of some supply-side improvements prevents it from being entirely dovish.

author: Jonathan Haskel
title: From lockdown to recovery - the economic effects of Covid-19 - speech by Jonathan Haskel
Key quote: It seems likely that such demand weakness will therefore drag on the economy and hold back the recovery.
Rationale: The speech by Jonathan Haskel highlights significant demand weaknesses and the risk of prolonged economic recovery due to consumer fear and potential unemployment. This suggests a cautious approach towards monetary policy, leaning towards maintaining the current low rate to support economic recovery.

author: Jonathan Haskel
title: Remarks by Jonathan Haskel on Covid-19 and monetary policy
Key quote: In conclusion, I believe the current stance of monetary policy is appropriate but, on balance, risks are to the downside.
Rationale: Haskel acknowledges the current unprecedented economic downturn but suggests some signs of recovery, while clearly expressing concern that risks are skewed to the downside. His emphasis on supporting recovery through asset purchases and not suggesting further immediate action implies a somewhat dovish stance leaning towards holding rates stable.

author: Jonathan Haskel
title: Monetary policy in the intangible economy - speech by Jonathan Haskel
Key quote: This much-discussed low interest rate environment we find ourselves in, reinforced by the trend towards intangible assets that I have discussed today, in part informs my recent votes on the MPC, where limited conventional monetary policy space means I continue to prefer to move now in order to ensure we achieve a sustainable return of inflation to target.
Rationale: The speech discusses various factors affecting monetary transmission and the natural rate of interest due to intangibles, without clear inclination towards immediate rate changes, indicating a balanced view on policy needs.

author: Jonathan Haskel
title: An end-of-year retrospective on the UK outlook and monetary policy - speech by Jonathan Haskel
Key quote: I voted to cut Bank rate at the November and December meetings of the MPC and I therefore wanted to set out my reasons for doing so.
Rationale: The speech focuses on risks like Brexit uncertainties and weak inflation, pointing to the need for looser monetary policy to avoid hitting the effective lower bound, justifying a dovish view and advocating for a rate cut.

author: Jonathan Haskel
title: Will UK investment bounce back? - speech by Jonathan Haskel
Key quote: Currently, it looks like uncertainty is holding investment back. If that continues, then there is a downside risk to the forecast.
Rationale: The speech expresses concerns about Brexit uncertainties weighing on investment, which could potentially lead to economic slowdown. However, it does not suggest an imminent need for an interest rate cut, indicating a more 'hold' position.

author: Silvana Tenreyro
title: Monetary policy in the face of large shocks − speech by Silvana Tenreyro
Key quote: Overall, I therefore judged that the tightening already in the pipeline would be sufficient to bring inflation back to, and most likely below, the target.
Rationale: The speech indicates a belief that current monetary policy is adequate to bring down inflation without further increases. This, combined with a cautious approach to additional tightening due to potential economic shocks, suggests a somewhat dovish stance leaning towards holding rates.

author: Silvana Tenreyro
title: Quantitative easing and quantitative tightening − speech by Silvana Tenreyro
Key quote: Given that outlook, I have voted for no change in Bank Rate in recent months, rather than further tightening.
Rationale: Silvana Tenreyro's speech emphasizes a preference to hold the Bank Rate due to the expectation that inflation will fall below target, indicating a less aggressive stance on tightening monetary policy further at this point.
description: In this speech Professor Silvana Tenreyro explains how Quantitative Easing, or QE, can help the MPC meet the inflation target by affecting interest rates. She also dispels some misconceptions about how QE works.

author: Silvana Tenreyro
title: The path to 2 per cent − speech by Silvana Tenreyro
Key quote: Too high a path for Bank Rate therefore risks oversteering inflation below target in the medium term.
Rationale: Despite the recent rate increase, Tenreyro expressed concerns about over-tightening and the potential for inflation to fall below target. This suggests a cautious approach to further rate hikes, indicating a more dovish stance compared to other MPC members.
description: In this speech Professor Silvana Tenreyro explains how energy prices affect inflation, and how that can depend on the strength of the labour market. She discusses how government and financial-market responses to the economic shock may inform the Monetary Policy Committee’s decision on interest rates. She sets out how these factors interact, and explains why in her assessment it was necessary to raise interest rates by 0.25 percentage points at the November 2022 Monetary Policy Committee Meeting.

author: Silvana Tenreyro
title: The economy and policy trade-offs - speech by Silvana Tenreyro
Key quote: A (significant) monetary tightening to bring down inflation quickly, would come at the cost of far greater output volatility.
Rationale: The speaker highlights the trade-offs in responding to supply shocks that increase inflation but reduce real incomes. The emphasis on avoiding high output volatility and recession indicates a reluctance towards aggressive policy tightening, suggesting a dovish stance with a likelihood to hold rates steady.

author: Silvana Tenreyro
title: International trade, global supply chains and monetary policy - speech by Silvana Tenreyro
Key quote: My policy votes will aim to strike a balance between these different effects and risks while bringing inflation back to target sustainably.
Rationale: The speech outlines that recent inflationary pressures are considered temporary, while the employment and output trends have not yet recovered to pre-pandemic levels. The focus on striking a balance between inflation and economic recovery suggests a cautious approach, likely leading to a hold on interest rates.
description: Professor Silvana Tenreyro says global supply chains can improve a country’s productivity and income. But the benefits they bring are not evenly spread across sectors. In the past, global supply chains have helped to reduce the effect of economic shocks in some parts of the world. The Covid crisis is different to previous shocks. But, on balance, countries can benefit from using global supply chains rather than producing things at home, she argues. Silvana then explains how current disruptions to supply chains will determine whether she believes interest rates in the UK need to be changed or not.

author: Silvana Tenreyro
title: Response to the Covid-19 pandemic: UK and US experiences - Speech by Silvana Tenreyro
Key quote: Since Covid took hold a year ago UK monetary policy has largely played a supporting role in mitigating the economic effects of the pandemic.
Rationale: The focus on assessing the impact of fiscal policy on monetary policy suggests a dovish stance, as the speaker is cautious about the recovery and emphasizes maintaining support. The prediction to 'Hold' is based on the emphasis on supporting the economy amidst uncertainties.

author: Silvana Tenreyro
title: Let’s talk about negative interest rates - speech by Silvana Tenreyro
Key quote: My overall assessment is that, while we can never have complete certainty, negative interest rates should with high likelihood boost UK growth and inflation.
Rationale: The speech extensively discusses the potential use of negative interest rates as a tool to provide economic stimulus, which suggests a dovish stance. The speaker indicates that negative rates could boost growth and encourages considering them as part of the monetary policy toolkit.

author: Silvana Tenreyro
title: Covid-19 and the economy: what are the lessons so far? - speech by Silvana Tenreyro
Key quote: To counteract those pressures and bring inflation back up towards our 2 per cent target, I voted to loosen monetary policy by expanding the stock of asset purchases by £100 billion.
Rationale: The speaker voted to loosen monetary policy due to disinflationary pressures. While this suggests a dovish stance, the readiness to act further indicates a somewhat cautious approach, thus 'somewhat dovish'. Given current actions, a 'Hold' on rates is more likely, with a higher probability.

author: Silvana Tenreyro
title: Monetary policy during pandemics: inflation before, during and after Covid-19 - speech by Silvana Tenreyro
Key quote: Our policy decisions will help ensure price stability by mitigating any deflationary pressures arising from recent events.
Rationale: Silvana Tenreyro discusses the profound economic impacts of Covid-19 and emphasizes efforts to minimize economic disruptions. The speech suggests that while inflation pressures are subdued, the MPC's actions are aimed at supporting the economy and maintaining price stability, indicating a somewhat dovish outlook. Given the current low policy rate of 0.1%, the likelihood is that rates will be held steady to provide continued support.

author: Silvana Tenreyro
title: Monetary policy and open questions in international macroeconomics - speech by Silvana Tenreyro
Key quote: I would argue that exchange-rate movements do affect exports, in a variety of ways.
Rationale: The speech discusses the idea that exchange-rate movements do affect exports and suggests that depreciations expand exports by various channels. However, the speaker cautions against taking macroeconomic estimates at face value and acknowledges potential mitigating policy responses. This somewhat dovish stance, combined with no strong indication of impending rate changes, suggests the speaker is likely to vote to hold rates.

author: Silvana Tenreyro
title: Understanding inflation: expectations and reality - speech by Silvana Tenreyro
Key quote: I still expect that in a smooth Brexit scenario, a small amount of policy tightening will be required over the forecast period to keep demand growing in line with supply.
Rationale: The speech primarily discusses the expectations and perceptions of inflation, emphasizing the importance of inflation expectations for monetary policy. The speaker stresses the role of financial literacy in understanding inflation expectations and discusses past experience and current global uncertainties affecting the UK economy. The steady policy holds a neutral tone with no immediate signal of a rate change, suggesting a hold in interest rates with a careful watch on the evolving economic circumstances.

author: Silvana Tenreyro
title: The elusive supply potential: monetary policy in times of uncertainty - speech by Silvana Tenreyro
Key quote: The recent softening in measures of underlying price inflation suggests to me that supply has been growing broadly in line with demand, and that we may still have some excess supply remaining.
Rationale: The speech indicates an acknowledgment of current uncertainties in supply potential and the impact of Brexit, yet the overall tone suggests a wait-and-see approach, reflecting a balance between risks to supply and demand. The cautious outlook does not advocate for immediate rate changes, implying a likely hold on current rates.

author: Silvana Tenreyro
title: Models in macroeconomics - speech by Silvana Tenreyro
Key quote: I expect that the tight labour market will continue to feed through into domestic cost pressures – I think that fears of a breakdown in the relationship between slack and inflation are misplaced.
Rationale: Silvana Tenreyro emphasizes a belief in the need for limited and gradual rate increases over the next few years, indicating a somewhat hawkish stance. However, acknowledges recent data weakness and suggests a wait-and-see approach, implying holding rates might be sensible in the short term.

author: Gertjan Vlieghe
title: Running out of room: revisiting the 3D perspective on low interest rates - Gertjan Vlieghe
Key quote: For all these reasons, I think it will remain appropriate to keep the current monetary stimulus in place for several quarters at least, and probably longer.
Rationale: The speaker emphasizes the necessity of maintaining monetary stimulus, citing temporary factors for inflation, risks from the virus, and the impact of ending government support schemes. This suggests a dovish stance towards monetary policy, indicating no immediate need for tightening.

author: Gertjan Vlieghe
title: What are government bond yields telling us about the economic outlook? - speech by Gertjan Vlieghe
Key quote: I suspect that upward medium-term inflation pressure will only emerge once economic slack has been fully eroded.
Rationale: The speech highlights temporary inflation pressures and emphasizes the importance of not tightening policy prematurely. Vlieghe also underscores uncertainty regarding the labor market and economy’s path out of the Covid crisis, suggesting cautiousness in altering monetary policy immediately.

author: Gertjan Vlieghe
title: An update on the economic outlook - speech by Gertjan Vlieghe
Key quote: The pandemic shock was fundamentally a disinflationary shock.
Rationale: The speech discusses concerns about persistent slack in the labor market and the potential need for further stimulus, indicating a dovish stance. While there is a possibility of negative rates, the speaker emphasizes waiting to respond to demand signs, which implies a likelihood of holding rates.

author: Gertjan Vlieghe
title: Assessing the health of the economy - speech by Gertjan Vlieghe
Key quote: In my view, the outlook for monetary policy is skewed towards adding further stimulus.
Rationale: The speech highlights the substantial economic slack, rising unemployment, and ongoing sectoral reallocations due to the pandemic. The speaker emphasizes potential further monetary stimulus, indicating a dovish stance and likelihood of supporting a rate cut.

author: Gertjan Vlieghe
title: Monetary policy and the Bank of England’s balance sheet - speech by Gertjan Vlieghe
Key quote: The current priority for monetary policy, with a lot of help from fiscal policy, is to return the economy to that pre-virus trajectory as soon as possible.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the severe economic contraction due to COVID-19 and highlights the use of monetary tools like QE to provide liquidity and prevent further economic downturn. The focus on maintaining monetary support and readiness for further action indicates a dovish stance. However, the current policy rate is already low at 0.1%, so a rate hold is the most likely action at the next meeting.

author: Gertjan Vlieghe
title: Monetary policy: adapting to a changed world - speech by Gertjan Vlieghe
Key quote: Our ability to ease further is significantly smaller than our ability to tighten.
Rationale: The speech focuses on the limited capacity for monetary policy to further ease due to the proximity of interest rates to their lower bound, indicating caution against rate increases despite current economic uncertainties. There is a recognition of the inability to significantly ease monetary policy further, highlighting the need for other measures. These points suggest a somewhat dovish stance but with a likelihood to hold rates in the near term.

author: Gertjan Vlieghe
title: Continuous improvements in communicating monetary policy - speech by Gertjan Vlieghe
Key quote: On balance I think it is more likely that I would move to cut Bank Rate towards the effective lower bound of close to 0% in the event of a no deal scenario.
Rationale: The speech focuses on the challenges of monetary policy communication and suggests improvements without proposing immediate policy changes. The acknowledgment of global and Brexit-related headwinds, alongside a preference for holding rates or considering cuts under certain scenarios, indicates a somewhat dovish stance.

author: Gertjan Vlieghe
title: The economic outlook: Fading global tailwinds, intensifying Brexit headwinds - speech by Gertjan Vlieghe
Key quote: I therefore consider that the appropriate pace of monetary tightening is somewhat slower than I judged it to be a year ago.
Rationale: The speech reflects concerns about global and domestic economic slowdown, heavy Brexit uncertainty, and a willingness to wait for more evidence before considering a rate hike, suggesting a move away from previous tightening.

author: Gertjan Vlieghe
title: The yield curve and QE - speech by Gertjan Vlieghe
Key quote: My view that QE works primarily via expectations, with additional powerful liquidity effects that are temporary and mainly relevant during periods of market stress, implies that unwinding QE need not have a material impact on the shape of the yield curve, or indeed on the economy, if properly communicated and done gradually.
Rationale: The speech suggests that QE is primarily effective through shaping expectations rather than significantly altering long-term interest rates. Given the current economic assessment and the outlined central bank strategies, it hints that the current policy rate is appropriate for the near term, leading to a 'Hold' prediction.

author: Gertjan Vlieghe
title: From asymmetry to symmetry: changing risks to the economic outlook - speech by Gertjan Vlieghe
Key quote: I expect that Bank Rate will need to rise further over the forecast period.
Rationale: The speech discusses the improvement in global economic conditions and the prospects of increased inflationary pressures, suggesting a need to increase interest rates gradually. This indicates a somewhat hawkish stance focused on preemptively managing inflation.

author: Gertjan Vlieghe
title: Real interest rates and risk - speech by Gertjan Vlieghe
Key quote: If these data trends of reducing slack, rising pay pressure, strengthening household spending and robust global growth continue, the appropriate time for a rise in Bank Rate might be as early as in the coming months.
Rationale: The speaker notes that although some medium-term dynamics don't show signs of turning yet, current data trends like reducing slack and rising wage pressure suggest that it may soon be appropriate to consider raising the Bank Rate.

author: Gertjan Vlieghe
title: Good policy vs accurate forecasts - speech by Gertjan Vlieghe
