Key quote: A rate hike that turns out to be premature is a more serious mistake than one that turns out to be somewhat late. Caution is warranted.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes caution in monetary policy due to observed slowdowns in household consumption and the asymmetry in easing versus tightening. While recognizing some upside risks, it suggests a preference for holding rates to avoid premature hikes in a context of subdued underlying inflation pressures.

author: Gertjan Vlieghe
title: Umbrellas don't cause rain - speech by Gertjan Vlieghe
Key quote: For now, given our current economic outlook, and given the level of the exchange rate and other asset prices that prevailed in early November, the best contribution that monetary policy can make to returning inflation to target while avoiding undesirable volatility in output growth is to keep interest rates where they are now.
Rationale: The speech indicates a willingness to tolerate a temporary rise in inflation to prevent slack in the economy, suggesting an inclination towards maintaining accommodative policy. This, combined with the observation that information and conditions have not materially altered since the last policy decision, suggests a 'Hold' decision is likely.

author: Gertjan Vlieghe
title: Monetary policy expectations and long term interest rates - speech by Gertjan Vlieghe
Key quote: Interest rates are low because that is what the economy needs in order to keep inflation expectations anchored.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the need for continued low interest rates due to persistent economic challenges and a low natural rate of interest. It suggests a cautious approach to monetary policy, anticipating rates to remain low for an extended period, which aligns with a somewhat dovish stance.

author: Gertjan Vlieghe
title: Debt, Demographics and the Distribution of Income: New challenges for monetary policy - speech by Gertjan...
Key quote: The possibility of this scenario makes me more patient, other things equal, before raising rates.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes concerns about the economic outlook and hints at patience regarding rate increases due to structural changes in debt, demographics, and distribution of income. Although recognizing growth, the speech indicates a preference to wait for stronger evidence of inflationary pressures before raising rates.

author: Jon Cunliffe
title: Monetary and financial stability and the invasion of Ukraine
Key quote: At the last MPC meeting, shortly after the invasion, I voted against increasing rates.
Rationale: Jon Cunliffe suggests the need to carefully consider both inflation and economic activity, indicating potential room to pause or moderate rate hikes considering the impact of external shocks and economic timing.
description: Speech by Sir Jon Cunliffe, Deputy Governor for Financial Stability of the Bank of England, at the European Economics & Financial Centre, London, 4 April 2022.

author: Jon Cunliffe
title: Financial stability and low for long
Key quote: It is this downward shift in the long-run real rate that has lain, in part, behind the Bank of England's message that any future increases in rates will be limited and we should not expect to see a return to the levels of policy rates we saw before the crisis.
Rationale: The speech highlights the persistence of low interest rates and discusses the challenges this presents, especially in terms of financial stability. The discussion about the need for limited rate increases suggests a cautious approach to monetary tightening, indicative of a somewhat dovish stance. The emphasis is on stability rather than immediate policy action, pointing towards an inclination to hold rates.
description: Speech by Sir Jon Cunliffe, Deputy Governor for Financial Stability of the Bank of England, at the Society of Professional Economists Annual Conference, London, 14 October 2019.

author: Jon Cunliffe
title: A little bit of stodginess?
Key quote: In short we are still learning about the relationships between key economic variables in the post crisis economy and are still a long way off the old rules of thumb. This for me still implies an approach with a little more resistance in our reaction to developments.
Rationale: Cunliffe emphasizes caution due to lingering uncertainties un the economy and expresses reluctance to change rates without more evidence, indicating a preference toward a dovish stance, but also acknowledges existing inflationary pressures, resulting in a 'Hold' prediction.
description: Speech by Sir Jon Cunliffe, Deputy Governor for Financial Stability of the Bank of England, at the Cumbria Chambers of Commerce, Kendal, 13 July 2018.

author: Jon Cunliffe
title: The Phillips curve - lower, flatter or in hiding?
Key quote: At the November meeting I voted against increasing Bank rate.
Rationale: Cunliffe expresses uncertainty about the current understanding of the Phillips curve and the domestic inflationary pressures, suggesting a cautious approach to policy adjustments. His emphasis on waiting for clear evidence of pay growth responsiveness indicates a neutral stance, supporting a hold on rate decisions until more data is available.
description: Speech by Sir Jon Cunliffe, Deputy Governor for Financial Stability of the Bank of England, to the Oxford Economics Society, Oxford, 14 November 2017.

author: Jon Cunliffe
title: Are firms underinvesting - and if so why?
Key quote: The efficiency and soundness of the mechanisms for channeling savings to investment remain a key element in the delivery of our now, exclusively public, responsibility to safeguard monetary and financial stability.
Rationale: The speech by Jon Cunliffe focuses on the analysis of investment trends and challenges in the British economy, without suggesting immediate changes to monetary policy. It discusses the various factors affecting investment but does not emphasize the need for a rate adjustment, indicating a neutral stance.
description: Speech by Sir Jon Cunliffe, Deputy Governor for Financial Stability of the Bank of England, to the Greater Birmingham Chamber of Commerce, Birmingham, 8 February 2017.

author: Jon Cunliffe
title: Why are interest rates low?
Key quote: My own view is that it can. The natural rate, according to most estimates, has risen since 2012 from its deep post-crisis trough. It is now closer to the zero mark but it's still likely to be negative.
Rationale: The speech discusses the reasons for low interest rates, highlights structural factors pushing rates down, and suggests that the natural rate is close to zero, implying a continued period of low rates. This indicates a dovish stance, but the acknowledgment of potential trade-offs due to inflation suggests a 'Hold' decision as the most balanced approach.
description: Speech by Sir Jon Cunliffe, Deputy Governor for Financial Stability of the Bank of England, at Manchester University, Manchester, 16 November 2016.

author: Jon Cunliffe
title: The UK economy post crisis - a series of unfortunate events?
Key quote: My central expectation remains that as the effects of the crisis continue to heal and as the deflationary effects of past sterling strength and oil price falls wane, domestic cost pressures will gradually push inflation back to target.
Rationale: Cunliffe's speech emphasizes the concept of 'slow healing' and the challenges faced by the UK economy, such as the impacts of deflationary shocks and global economic uncertainty. His outlook does not indicate an immediate need for monetary tightening, thus suggesting a dovish stance but still recognizing potential risks that do not warrant rate cuts yet.
description: Speech by Sir Jon Cunliffe, Deputy Governor for Financial Stability of the Bank of England, at the Centre for International Business Studies, London South Bank University, London, 24 February 2016.

author: Jon Cunliffe
title: Credit - can trees grow to the sky?
Key quote: Credit cannot grow faster than the economy forever. But the level of debt and the rate of growth of credit that the economy can sustain is not fixed.
Rationale: The speech discusses the history and the implications of credit growth relative to GDP without leaning towards a decisive monetary action. It acknowledges the risks associated with high levels of debt but does not suggest immediate changes to the policy rate, indicating a preference for assessing stable conditions.
description: Speech by Sir Jon Cunliffe, Deputy Governor for Financial Stability of the Bank of England, at the British Property Federation Annual Residential Investment Conference, London, 9 February 2016.

author: Andrew G Haldane
title: Thirty years of hurt, never stopped me dreaming
Key quote: By the end of this year, I expect UK inflation to be nearer 4% than 3%.
Rationale: Haldane expresses significant concern over rising inflation and the potential need for the Bank to take action to address these pressures, which aligns with a more hawkish stance on monetary policy. His warnings about the risks of inflation becoming entrenched suggest a strong argument for raising interest rates.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew G Haldane, Executive Director and Chief Economist of the Bank of England, at the Institute for Government, 30 June 2021.

author: Andrew G Haldane
title: Inflation - a tiger by the tail?
Key quote: But, for me, there is a tangible risk inflation proves more difficult to tame, requiring monetary policymakers to act more assertively than is currently priced into financial markets.
Rationale: The speech highlights the risk of rising inflation due to demand outpacing supply and hints that policymakers may need to be assertive, suggesting some hawkish sentiment. However, the acknowledgment of significant uncertainty and balanced risks implies a preference to hold rather than immediately raise rates.
description: Pre-recorded speech by Mr Andrew G Haldane, Executive Director and Chief Economist of the Bank of England, given online, 26 February 2021.

author: Andrew G Haldane
title: What has central bank independence ever done for us?
Key quote: The justification for the QE actions taken by the MPC this year, and which I have supported, is that they will support demand and act as an insurance policy against any premature and undesirable rise in borrowing costs which would otherwise risk setting back the economic recovery and put at risk hitting the inflation target.
Rationale: The speech is neutral as Haldane discusses the importance of central bank independence without indicating a clear lean toward more easing or tightening. He acknowledges QE as necessary for economic support but does not imply further rate cuts or hikes. Given the context, it's likely he would vote to hold the interest rate.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew G Haldane, Executive Director and Chief Economist of the Bank of England, at the UCL Economists' Society Economics Conference, 28 November 2020.

author: Andrew G Haldane
title: Avoiding economic anxiety
Key quote: The MPC has also made clear that it stands ready to take whatever further action is needed to support the economy and return inflation sustainably to target, should that prove necessary.
Rationale: The speech stresses the importance of avoiding economic anxiety and recognizing positive economic developments, with an emphasis on maintaining current monetary policy measures to support recovery. Haldane's comments suggest a cautious but optimistic outlook, likely leading to 'Hold' rather than a rate change at the next meeting.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew G Haldane, Executive Director and Chief Economist of the Bank of England, at the Cheshire and Warrington LEP Economic Summit Webinar, 30 September 2020.

author: Andrew G Haldane
title: The second quarter
Key quote: Subsequent positive news on demand has, in my opinion, more than counterbalanced the rise in downside risks to employment.
Rationale: Andrew Haldane notes faster-than-expected economic recovery and expresses optimism about consumer spending and economic outlook. This indicates a slightly hawkish stance, as he seems optimistic about the economy's ability to recover, reducing the immediate need for more aggressive monetary easing. However, he recognizes the downside risks, especially in unemployment, which supports a decision to hold rates.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew G Haldane, Executive Director and Chief Economist of the Bank of England, during an online webinar, London, 30 June 2020.

author: Andrew G Haldane
title: Climbing the jobs ladder
Key quote: My personal view, though, is that I would be very cautious about considering a monetary policy loosening, barring some sharp economic downturn.
Rationale: Despite some acknowledgment of downside risks, Haldane expresses caution about loosening monetary policy. He notes the tight labor market, steady growth, and concerns about growing wage pressures, suggesting that holding rates while awaiting more clarity on economic developments is most prudent.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew G Haldane, Executive Director and Chief Economist of the Bank of England, Scunthorpe, 23 July 2019.

author: Andrew G Haldane
title: Andrew Haldane: Pay power
Key quote: A year on, I think there is more compelling evidence of a new dawn breaking for pay growth, albeit with the light filtering through only slowly.
Rationale: Andrew Haldane discusses both positive indicators in wage growth and employment levels and the structural and cyclical issues that might influence future wage growth. His remarks suggest a balanced outlook without strong impetus to either raise or cut rates at this time.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew G Haldane, Executive Director and Chief Economist of the Bank of England, at the Acas "Future of Work" Conference, London, 10 October 2018.

author: Andrew G Haldane
title: Andrew Haldane: Market power and monetary policy
Key quote: The net effect of increased market power could be a potentially significant rise in inflation (but less so output) variability, relative to the counterfactual case of stable and static mark-ups.
Rationale: The speech discusses the complex implications of market power on monetary policy, highlighting both potential upward and downward pressures on inflation and output variability. The emphasis is on understanding and research rather than immediate policy action, suggesting a neutral stance.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew G Haldane, Executive Director and Chief Economist of the Bank of England, at at "Changing Market Structure and Implications for Monetary Policy", a symposium sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, Jackson Hole, Wyoming, 24 August 2018.

author: Andrew G Haldane
title: How monetary policy affects your GDP
Key quote: There is nothing to suggest monetary policy has had significant effects on either income or wealth inequality in the UK over recent years.
Rationale: Andrew Haldane's speech provides a balanced view on the distributional impact of past monetary policy, showing both the benefits and addressing public perceptions. His emphasis is on explaining the effects rather than suggesting a policy change, which aligns with a neutral standpoint.
description: Text of the Finch Lecture by Mr Andrew G Haldane, Executive Director and Chief Economist of the Bank of England, at the University of Melbourne, Melbourne, 10 April 2018.

author: Andrew G Haldane
title: Work, wages and monetary policy
Key quote: Having weighed the evidence, I think that the balance of risks associated with tightening 'too early', on the one hand, and 'too late', on the other, has swung materially towards the latter in the past six to nine months.
Rationale: Haldane acknowledges improved global economic conditions and diminishing inflation risks, suggesting an inclination towards tightening policy. He highlights the need for a partial withdrawal of additional policy insurance, indicating a tilt towards rate hikes in the near future.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew G Haldane, Executive Director and Chief Economist of the Bank of England, at the National Science and Media Museum, Bradford, 20 June 2017.

author: Andrew G Haldane
title: A little more conversation - A little less action
Key quote: Tonight, I want to explore one avenue for doing so rethinking how and with whom central banks engage.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the importance of central bank communication and engagement, but does not hint at any immediate changes to interest rates, suggesting more of a focus on stability and trust-building rather than aggressive policy action. This indicates a 'Somewhat hawkish' stance due to the focus on central bank's increasing responsibilities and operational independence, suggesting a tendency to maintain or gradually tighten current policy to safeguard the economy.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew G Haldane, Executive Director and Chief Economist of the Bank of England, at the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco Macroeconomics and Monetary Policy Conference, San Francisco, 31 March 2017.

author: Andrew G Haldane
title: One Car, Two Car, Red Car, Blue Car
Key quote: My personal view is that this provides grounds for not proceeding too hastily with any tightening of the monetary policy stance.
Rationale: Andrew Haldane acknowledges regional economic challenges, outlines the role of monetary policy in supporting the economy, and emphasizes the importance of industrial policy for long-term growth. Though he is cautious about tightening, his stance is more about maintaining current policy, indicating a somewhat dovish position.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew G Haldane, Executive Director and Chief Economist of the Bank of England, at the Materials Processing Institute, Redcar, 2 December 2016.

author: Andrew G Haldane
title: Whose recovery?
Key quote: In my personal view, this means a material easing of monetary policy is likely to be needed, as one part of a collective policy response aimed at helping protect the economy and jobs from a downturn.
Rationale: Andrew Haldane emphasizes the risks of slowing growth and increased uncertainty following the Brexit vote. He argues for easing policy as a material step to support the economy, indicating a somewhat dovish stance.
description: Speech by Mr Andrew G Haldane, Executive Director and Chief Economist of the Bank of England, in Port Talbot, Wales, 30 June 2016.

author: Mark Carney
title: A framework for all seasons?
Key quote: As is entirely appropriate, there is a debate at the MPC over the relative merits of near term stimulus to reinforce the expected recovery in UK growth and inflation.
Rationale: Mark Carney's speech highlighted both potential upside and downside risks to the UK economy, suggesting a balanced view. There was mention of reviewing monetary policy tools but no strong signaling of immediate rate changes, indicating a likely 'Hold' at the next meeting.
description: Speech by Mr Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England, at the Bank of England Research Workshop on "The Future of Inflation Targeting", London, 9 January 2020.

author: Mark Carney
title: The growing challenges for monetary policy in the current international monetary and financial system
Key quote: In my view, the appropriate policy path would be more likely to ease than not, using the flexibility in the MPC's remit to lengthen the period over which inflation is returned to target.
Rationale: Mark Carney acknowledges significant uncertainties related to Brexit and global economic headwinds. While he notes the potential need to ease monetary policy, he does not explicitly call for immediate rate cuts, suggesting a preference for holding rates while carefully assessing developments.
description: Speech by Mr Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England, at "Challenges for Monetary Policy", a symposium sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, Jackson Hole, Wyoming, 23 August 2019.

author: Mark Carney
title: Sea change
Key quote: For now, a global trade war and a No Deal Brexit remain growing possibilities not certainties. Monetary policy must address the consequences of such uncertainty for the behaviour of businesses, households and financial markets.
Rationale: Mark Carney highlights growing trade tensions and their potential negative impact on global and UK growth. Though there is caution around global risks, there is no immediate indication of rate cuts, suggesting a 'hold' on rates while monitoring developments.
description: Speech by Mr Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England, at the Local Government Association Annual Conference and Exhibition 2019, Bournemouth, 2 July 2019.

author: Mark Carney
title: The global outlook
Key quote: Provided the expansion continues, a modest tightening of monetary policy over time will likely be sufficient to achieve inflation targets.
Rationale: Carney recognizes the slowdown in global momentum and highlights risks like China and de-globalization but also notes that global growth may eventually stabilize. His speech suggests caution rather than immediate tightening or loosening of monetary policy, indicating a likely preference to hold rates.
description: Speech by Mr Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England, at the Financial Times event in Frobisher Hall, the Barbican, London, 12 February 2019.

author: Mark Carney
title: True finance - ten years after the financial crisis
Key quote: The reforms of the past decade have put in place a new financial system that could, with time, regain people's confidence.
Rationale: Mark Carney's speech is focused on the evaluation of financial system stability and reforms post-crisis rather than indicating a strong hawkish or dovish stance. The focus on maintaining reforms and preparation for potential risks such as Brexit suggests a more neutral and precautionary approach by the Bank of England.
description: Speech by Mr Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England and Chair of the Financial Stability Board, at the Economic Club of New York, New York City, 19 October 2018.

author: Mark Carney
title: From protectionism to prosperity
Key quote: Overall, recent domestic data suggest the economy is evolving largely in line with the May Inflation Report projections, which see demand growing at rates slightly above those of supply and domestic cost pressures building.
Rationale: Despite acknowledging risks from protectionist measures and uncertainties surrounding Brexit, Carney's speech indicates the UK economy is performing in line with projections, leading to a balanced view of economic growth and inflation pressures.
description: Speech by Mr Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England, at the Northern Powerhouse Business Summit, "Great Exhibition of the North", Newcastle, 5 July 2018.

author: Mark Carney
title: New economy, new finance, new bank
Key quote: The MPC now intends not to reduce the stock of purchased assets until Bank Rate reaches around 1.5%.
Rationale: Carney's speech outlines plans for cautious unwinding of asset purchases and emphasizes readiness to manage the financial system's evolution. While acknowledging the risks of global changes, offers an optimistic view of responsible openness and innovation, suggesting a somewhat hawkish stance with an inclination towards maintaining current rates while watching closely.
description: Speech by Mr Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England, at The Mansion House, London, 21 June 2018.

author: Mark Carney
title: Guidance, contingencies and Brexit
Key quote: From a monetary policy perspective, the Bank of England is ready for Brexit whatever form it takes.
Rationale: Mark Carney emphasizes readiness and adaptability in monetary policy amidst Brexit uncertainties, suggesting a balanced stance where future actions depend on economic developments, leading to a neutral outlook.
description: Speech by Mr Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England and Chairman of the Financial Stability Board, to the Society of Professional Economists, London, 24 May 2018.

author: Mark Carney
title: 20 years of independent monetary policy making in the United Kingdom
Key quote: Monetary policy will be set to achieve the inflation target in a way that helps smooth real adjustment in the economy and supports jobs in the wake of very large external forces.
Rationale: The speech reflects a commitment to maintaining price stability while acknowledging the economic adjustments necessary due to Brexit, indicating no immediate bias towards altering interest rates.
description: Opening remarks by Mr Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England and Chairman of the Financial Stability Board, at the Bank of England "Independence - 20 years on" Conference, London, 28 September 2017.

author: Mark Carney
title: [De]Globalisation and inflation
Key quote: Any prospective increases in Bank Rate would be expected to be at a gradual pace and to a limited extent, and to be consistent with monetary policy continuing to provide substantial support to the economy.
Rationale: The address highlighted concerns about Brexit's potential inflationary pressures but also acknowledged the subdued growth outlook and uncertainties. While indicating a possible modest tightening of monetary policy in response to reduced slack, the emphasis on proceeding gradually and maintaining support overall suggests a dovish tilt.
description: Text of the 2017 IMF Michel Camdessus Central Banking Lecture by Mr Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England and Chairman of the Financial Stability Board, Washington DC, 18 September 2017.

author: Mark Carney
title: Policy Panel - Investment and growth in advanced economies
Key quote: Some removal of monetary stimulus is likely to become necessary if the trade-off facing the MPC continues to lessen and the policy decision accordingly becomes more conventional.
Rationale: Mark Carney highlights that some removal of stimulus may become necessary, indicating a somewhat dovish stance as he is not advocating an immediate rate hike. He discusses uncertainties and a cautious approach, pointing towards maintaining the current policy stance for now.
description: Remarks by Mr Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England and Chairman of the Financial Stability Board, at the 2017 ECB Forum on Central Banking, Sintra, 28 June 2017.

author: Mark Carney
title: A fine balance
Key quote: From my perspective, given the mixed signals on consumer spending and business investment, and given the still subdued domestic inflationary pressures, in particular anaemic wage growth, now is not yet the time to begin that adjustment.
Rationale: While Mark Carney acknowledges the erosion of spare capacity and the diminishing trade-off between inflation and support for economic activity, he expresses a cautious approach, suggesting that it is not yet time to adjust the monetary policy. This indicates a somewhat dovish stance, likely leaning towards maintaining the current policy rate.
description: Speech by Mr Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England and Chairman of the Financial Stability Board, at the Lord Mayor's Banquet for Bankers and Merchants of the City of London, Mansion House, London, 20 June 2017.

author: Mark Carney
title: What a difference a decade makes
Key quote: The biggest question now is how to best take advantage of these years of hard work.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes the progress made in financial reforms and the need for dynamic, cooperative implementation but does not explicitly indicate a major shift in monetary policy direction, suggesting a neutral stance.
description: Remarks by Mr Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England and Chairman of the Financial Stability Board, at the Institute of International Financ's Washington Policy Summit, the Reagan Centre, Washington DC, 20 April 2017.

author: Mark Carney
title: Lambda
Key quote: In November, the MPC reiterated that we were choosing a period of somewhat higher consumer price inflation in exchange for a more modest increase in unemployment.
Rationale: Mark Carney provides a balanced view on the importance of considering both inflation risks and the trade-offs involving real economic indicators like employment and output. The speech acknowledges the need for stability but suggests careful monitoring and potential adjustments without indicating a direct policy shift at this moment.
description: Speech by Mr Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England and Chairman of the Financial Stability Board, at the London School of Economics, London, 16 January 2017.

author: Mark Carney
title: The spectre of monetarism
Key quote: The MPC is choosing a period of somewhat higher consumer price inflation in exchange for a more modest increase in unemployment.
Rationale: Governor Mark Carney's speech acknowledges economic challenges and emphasizes the balancing act required in monetary policy. While there's a recognition of economic uncertainties, he leans towards holding the current monetary policy stance to avoid excessive unemployment, indicating cautiousness rather than urgency to change interest rates.
description: Text of the Roscoe Lecture by Mr Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England and Chairman of the Financial Stability Board, John Moores University, Liverpool, 5 December 2016.

author: Mark Carney
title: Uncertainty, the economy and policy
Key quote: The economic outlook has deteriorated and some monetary policy easing will likely be required over the summer.
Rationale: Carney's speech acknowledges the deteriorated economic outlook and suggests monetary policy easing will likely be required, which implies a dovish leaning towards rate cuts to stimulate the economy amid Brexit uncertainties.
description: Speech by Mr Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England and Chairman of the Financial Stability Board, at the Bank of England, London, 30 June 2016.

author: Mark Carney
title: Redeeming an unforgiving world
Key quote: The global economy risks becoming trapped in a low growth, low inflation, low interest rate equilibrium.
Rationale: The speech highlights concerns about low global growth and inflation, and emphasizes the challenges faced by central banks. While it acknowledges the effectiveness of past monetary stimulus, it also suggests that central banks still have tools available but cautions against relying solely on monetary policy. This suggests a somewhat dovish stance, with a likelihood of holding rates steady to avoid tightening financial conditions in a fragile global environment.
description: Remarks by Mr Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England and Chairman of the Financial Stability Board, at the 8th Annual Institute of International Finance G20 conference, Shanghai, 26 February 2016.

author: Mark Carney
title: The turn of the year
Key quote: Well the year has turned, and, in my view, the decision proved straightforward: now is not yet the time to raise interest rates.
Rationale: Governor Carney suggests that global economic weakness, low inflation, and domestic cost growth indicate that it is not yet time to raise rates, indicating a somewhat dovish stance.
description: Text of the Peston Lecture by Mr Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England and Chairman of the Financial Stability Board, at the Queen Mary University of London, London, 19 January 2016.

author: Minouche Shafik
title: Small is beautiful but big is necessary
Key quote: It seems likely to me that further monetary stimulus will be required at some point in order to help ensure that a slowdown in economic activity doesn't turn into something more pernicious.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges the need for monetary stimulus to help with the economic transition post-referendum, hinting that further easing may be required. However, Minouche Shafik also suggests that the timing of such actions will depend on future data, indicating a cautious, somewhat dovish stance but not an immediate move to cut rates.
description: Speech by Ms Minouche Shafik, Deputy Governor for Markets and Banking of the Bank of England, at the Bloomberg Markets Most Influential conference, London, 28 September 2016.

author: Minouche Shafik
title: "Passthrough Efficiency in the Fed's new Monetary Policy Setting"
Key quote: This month the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) - of which I am a member - voted to introduce a package of measures to support the necessary adjustments of the UK economy as it responds to the decision to leave the European Union.
Rationale: The speech indicates that the Bank of England has recently reduced rates and introduced additional measures to support monetary policy transmission. The measures aim to reinforce the transmission of very low interest rates to the real economy. This suggests a dovish stance, although it highlights the current setup and does not explicitly indicate further easing, thus the prediction is a 'Hold'.
description: Remarks by Ms Minouche Shafik, Deputy Governor for Markets and Banking of the Bank of England, as a discussant of "Passthrough Efficiency in the Fed's new Monetary Policy Setting" by Mr Darell Duffie and Mr Arvind Krishnamurthy, at the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City Economic Symposium "Designing resilient monetary policy frameworks for the future", Jackson Hole, Wyoming, 26 August 2016.

author: Minouche Shafik
title: 14 December 2015 Treading carefully - speech by Minouche Shafik Treading carefully - speech by Minouche Shafik
Key quote: I will wait until I am convinced that wage growth will be sustained at a level consistent with inflation returning to target before voting for an increase in Bank Rate.
Rationale: The speech emphasizes caution due to uncertainties in the economy and expresses a preference for waiting for clearer signs of wage growth and sustained inflation targeting. This suggests a somewhat dovish stance with high probability of holding rates for the time being.

author: Minouche Shafik
title: Dealing with change: Liquidity in evolving market structures - speech by Minouche Shafik
Key quote: Monetary policy makers in the US and UK will likely consider it appropriate to gradually tighten monetary policy should the recovery in their respective economies continue.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges the possibility of gradual monetary policy tightening but does not strongly advocate for immediate action, instead referring to potential future policy normalization. This suggests a balanced view, hence a 'Neutral' label, predicting that rates will likely be held until further economic recovery is observed.

author: Minouche Shafik
title: The Interaction of Monetary and Macroprudential Policy - speech by Minouche Shafik
Key quote: So in a first best world where the institutional set up and macro-prudential tools are available, I would let them do the leaning first rather than wield the heavy hammer of monetary policy.
Rationale: The speech discusses the importance of using macroprudential policy tools to handle financial stability risks and suggests monetary policy normalization. This indicates a leaning toward a more hawkish stance but underlines the complexity of coordination across borders.

author: Minouche Shafik
title: Interpreting the yield curve: warning or opportunity? - speech by Minouche Shafik
Key quote: Indeed, doing so has been my primary motivation in not voting for an increase in Bank Rate over my first 10 months on the MPC.
Rationale: The speech acknowledges the persistence of risks and headwinds but suggests some optimism about the gradual easing of these issues. The speaker emphasizes previous actions not to raise rates and the continuation of accommodative monetary policy, indicating a stance that leans towards caution rather than aggressive monetary tightening.

author: Minouche Shafik
title: Goodbye ambiguity, hello clarity: the Bank of England's relationship with financial markets - speech...
Key quote: Looking forward, it seems to me that the most likely next move in monetary policy will be a gradual and limited increase in interest rates.

description: To mark the anniversary of the FXJSC, founded in November 1973, Andrew Bailey surveys some of the key thematic changes seen in FX markets over the past 50 years – from the role of currencies in macroeconomic frameworks; to the huge diversification in the range of market participants, the trading and settlement technologies they use; and the evolving toolkit needed to maintain safety, soundness and financial stability. Against that dynamic backdrop, two features of the market have remained constant – the UK’s position as the largest single FX centre; and the important role played by the FXJSC as a forum for facilitating market functioning, in both calm and unsettled times. The strengths of the FXJSC model has seen it adopted by many other national centres, as well as the Global Foreign Exchange Committee, established in 2017 to own the new FX Global Code.
